ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Color centers and dynamic emission of Eu2+ ion doped halosilicate Ca10Si6O21Cl2

Affiliation.OrgDivision: College of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Materials Science
Department of Physics and Interdisciplinary Program of Biomedical Engineering

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Rare earth (Eu2+) ion doped halosilicate Ca10Si6O21Cl2 was prepared by a solid state reaction method. The X-ray powder diffraction patterns, the scanning electron micrographs, the photoluminescence excitation and emission spectra, and the thermal stability were measured. The luminescence properties were investigated by dynamic excitation of a pulsed UV laser. Two typical Eu2+ emission centers were suggested from two different Ca2+ cation sites in the lattice. With increasing Eu2+-doping concentration, energy transfer between the two Eu2+ centers can happen. The emission mechanism is discussed by analyzing the excitation and emission spectra, the concentration-dependent luminescence intensity, and the lifetimes. The colors of Ca10Si6O21Cl2:Eu2+ change from bluish green to yellowish green by increasing the Eu2+-doping concentration. The luminescence stability with temperature was evaluated by the activation energy for thermal quenching.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Rare earth (RE) ion activated compounds have been widely investigated to develop useful luminescent materials in lighting, displays, and optoelectronic devices [1–6]. The Eu2+ ion is one of the most popular activators doped in luminescence materials. Transitions between 4f7 ground state and 4f65d1 excited state configurations of Eu2+ are very sensitive to the crystal field in the lattice; consequently, luminescence spectra of Eu2+ ions usually present a broad band varying from ultraviolet to red depending on the host. Eu2+-doped materials have been intensively investigated in rich kinds of hosts because of their potential applications as phosphors [7–11].

Eu2+-doped silicates present strong absorption in the UV-to-visible spectral region, usually exhibit efficient luminescence [12, 13], and have been paid continuous attention for the significant applications in luminescence and displays [14–16]. Silicates have rigid frameworks with covalent Si–O bonds and provide a distorted surrounding around Eu2+. Especially, halide-containing silicates have many excellent properties, such as low synthesis temperatures, chemical and physical stabilities, and preferable thermal stabilities. This makes them a suitable host lattice for luminescence materials in lighting [17–20].

In silicate lattices, introduction of halide causes a red shift of the excitation and emission band of Eu2+ ions because Cl− ions with a strong coordination effect can strengthen the crystal-field splitting of Eu2+ ions. This is a benefit for developing new phosphors that could be effectively excited in the near-ultraviolet and blue wavelength ranges. For example, the main emission peak of Eu2+-activated Ca12Al10.6Si3.4O32Cl5.4 (maximum emission at 500 nm) exhibits a red shift in comparison with that of Eu2+-activated Ca12Al14O33 (442 nm) due to the introduction of Cl− ions [21]. In recent years, Eu2+-activated alkaline earth halosilicates have been widely investigated to develop new phosphors, for example Ca3SiO4Cl2:Eu2+ [22], Ca3SiO4Cl2:Eu2+ [23], Ca7(SiO4)2Cl6:Eu2+ [24], Ca8MgSiO44Cl2:Eu2+ [25], Ca12Al10.6Si3.4O32Cl5.4:Eu2+ [21], Ca6Sr4(Si2O7)3Cl2:Eu2+ [26], Sr5SiO4Cl6:Eu2+ [27], Sr4Si3O8Cl4:Eu2+ [28], Sr8Si4O12Cl:Eu2+ [28], Ba5SiO4(F,Cl)6:Eu2+ [29], and Ba5SiO4F,Cl6:Eu2+ [30, 31].

Calcium silicate chloride Ca10Si6O21Cl2 is a kind of nesosilicate mineral, which was firstly reported to have an orthorhombic structure with basic skeleton composed by isolated Si2O7 [32]. It has a monoclinic structure with unit cell lattice constants a=18.665 Å, b=14.107 Å, c=18.139 Å, Z=8, and V=4439.20 Å3. In 2007, Ding et al. [33] reported the excitation and emission spectra and temperature properties of Ca10Si6O21Cl2:Eu2+. As a green phosphor, Eu2+-doped Ca10Si6O21Cl2 might be promisingly applicable for new optical devices.

In this work, we give a deep investigation of luminescence properties of Eu2+-doped Ca10Si6O21Cl2. The X-ray powder diffraction, the scanning electron micrographs (SEM), and the emission and excitation spectra were measured. Two emission centers of Eu2+ were identified by the luminescence and decay curves. The activation energy for thermal quenching (ΔE) was calculated. The spectroscopic results are discussed in relation to the existence of different crystallographic sites in Eu2+-doped Ca10Si6O21Cl2.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para: Ca10Si6O21Cl2:xEu2+ (x=0.01–0.1) phosphors were prepared by conventional solid-state reaction. The raw material is a mixture of reagent-grade CaCO3, SiO2, CaF2, and Eu2O3. For an example of Ca10Si6O21Cl2:0.05Eu2+, the raw materials were weighed according to the stoichiometric mole component of 5CaCl2⋅Ca4.5Eu0.5(Si6O21). Firstly, the mixture of CaCO3 (1.126 g), SiO2 (0.902 g), and Eu2O3 (0.22 g) was thoroughly mixed in acetone and then heated to 850–900 °C in a crucible and kept at this temperature for 5–10 h in air. Then the powder was fully mixed again by adding 0.372 g CaCl2 and heated at 1000–1100 °C for 5–10 h in a covered crucible imbedded in active carbon.

The phase purity was checked by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis collected on a Rigaku D/Max diffractometer operating at 40 kV, 30 mA with Bragg–Brentano geometry using Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5405 Å). The morphology of the powder was observed using a JEOL-5600 scanning electron microscope. The photoluminescence excitation and emission spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer LS-50B luminescence spectrometer. The luminescence decay was measured using the third harmonic (355 nm) of a pulsed Nd:YAG laser.

Section2.Heading: The phase formation and particle morphology
Section2.Para:
Eu2+-doped Ca10Si6O21Cl2 samples were checked by powder XRD measurements, which are shown in Fig. 1a. The XRD patterns are compared with the PDF2 standard card number no. 48-0827 selected in the International Centre for Diffraction Data (ICDD) database. The XRD peaks in the pattern can be well indexed according to the standard card no. 48-0827. The result indicates that doping of Eu2+ into the lattices does not induce any impurity phase.
Fig. 1
(a) XRD patterns of Ca10Si6O21Cl2:xEu2+ (x=0.01, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.09) phosphors and the standard card PDF2 no. 48-0827; (b) the dependences of lattice parameter a and of unit-cell volume on Eu2+ doping

The effective ionic radius of Ca2+ (r=1.120 Å, CN=8) is close to that of Eu2+ (r=1.25 Å, CN=8), so Eu2+ ions are suggested to occupy the Ca2+ sites in the lattices [34]. The influences of Eu2+ doping on the lattice parameter a and the unit cells of the host are presented in Fig. 1b. The lattice parameter a increases from 18.665 (x=0) to 18.866 Å (x=0.09) and the unit-cell volume from 4439 (x=0) to 4491 Å3 (x=0.09). This agrees with the fact that the diffraction peaks shift toward smaller two-theta angles with increasing Eu2+ doping; for example, the two-theta angles for the diffraction peak [233] can be observed to be 29.13∘, 28.91∘, 28.72∘, and 28.56∘ for the samples with x=0.01, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.09, respectively. The expansion should be due to the smaller size of Ca2+ than Eu2+ ions.

All the samples were prepared by the solid state reaction method. The particle size and morphology have no changes with different Eu2+ doping. Figure 2 shows the representative SEM micrograph of Ca10Si6O21Cl2:0.07Eu2+. The phosphors have an irregular elliptical or ball shape, and the particle sizes of the obtained Ca10Si6O21Cl2:Eu2+ powders are about 2–5 μm with a fairly narrow size distribution. There was no aggregation of the particles.
Fig. 2
The SEM micrographs of Ca10Si6O21Cl2:0.07Eu2+ phosphor

Section2.Heading: Photoluminescence properties
Section2.Para:
Figure 3 shows the luminescence spectra of Ca10Si6O21Cl2:xEu2+ (x=0.01, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.09) under the excitation of 355 nm of a YAG:Nd laser. The spectra have a very broad wavelength from 400 nm to 700 nm, which is from Eu2+ transitions 4f65d1→4f7 (8S7/2). The spectra show two distinct emission bands centered at about 430 nm and 540 nm, indicating that there are two different Eu2+ centers, which are denoted as EuI and EuII, respectively. This is very different from the reported result by Ding et al. [33] that there is only one emission at 505 nm in the emission spectra of Ca10Si6O21Cl2:Eu2+.
Fig. 3
The normalized luminescence spectra of Ca10Si6O21Cl2:xEu2+ phosphor for x=0.01 (a), x=0.05 (b), x=0.07 (c), and x=0.09 (d) under the excitation of 355 nm YAG:Nd3+ laser. Each spectrum was deconvoluted by two Gaussian components, which are denoted as EuI and EuII

The spectra in Fig. 3 could be decomposed into at least two Gaussian components; one is in the high-energy region at about 430 nm (EuI) and the other is in the lower-wavelength region at about 540 nm (EuII). The luminescence properties of Ca10Si6O21Cl2:Eu2+ show a dependence on the Eu2+-doping concentration as presented in Fig. 4, which can be gathered as follows:
(1)
The optimum Eu2+-doping level with the maximum luminescence intensity is 7.0 mol%. Figure 4a shows the experimental dependence of luminescence intensity on the Eu2+ doping. The luminescence intensity increases with enhancing Eu2+ doping until a maximum intensity at about x=0.07 is reached, and then it decreases because of a conventional concentration-quenching process.
Fig. 4
Eu2+-doping-concentration-dependent (a) the experimental luminescence intensity by integrated areas of each spectrum; (b) the relative integrated intensity ratio of I EuII/I EuI; (c) the emission wavelength of EuI; (d) the red shift of the emission position of EuII
(2)
The luminescence contribution from EuII becomes larger with increasing Eu2+ doping. The relative intensity ratio between EuI and EuII (I EuI/I EuII) of Ca10Si6O21Cl2:xEu2+ (x=0.01–0.09) is displayed in Fig. 4b. The luminescence intensities of EuI and EuII have great changes with increasing Eu2+ doping. With the increase of Eu2+-doping concentration, the emission intensity of the 540 nm band increases; however, the 430 nm emission band deceases quickly.
(3)
With increasing doping concentration, the luminescence of EuI keeps nearly the same wavelength at 430 nm (Fig. 4c);, however, the emission of the EuII center shows a red shift (Fig. 4d). As shown in Fig. 3, by varying the doping level of Eu2+, the maximum of the emission band can be tuned from 526 nm (x=0.01, Fig. 3a), to 529 nm (x=0.05, Fig. 3b), to 535 nm (x=0.07, Fig. 3c), and to 540 nm (x=0.09, Fig. 3d).
(4)
Some emission peaks from 5D0→7F J (J=0, 1, 2, and 3) transitions of Eu3+ ions in the spectrum of the Ca10Si6O21Cl2:0.09Eu2+ sample appear (Fig. 3d), indicating that some Eu3+ ions cannot be totally reduced at higher doping levels. The strongest emission transition of Eu3+ ions is 618 nm from 5D0→7F2.
(5)
The luminescence color can be tunable with increasing Eu2+ doping because of the red shift of emission and the changes of EuI/EuII. Figure 5 shows the CIE chromaticity diagram for Ca10Si6O21Cl2:xEu2+ (x=0.01–0.09) calculated from emission spectra. With increasing Eu2+ doping, the CIE coordinates shift from bluish green (0.22,0.36) (x=0.01) to yellowish green color (0.331,0.432) (x=0.09). The sample with the maximum luminescence at x=0.07 has CIE coordinates of (0.313,0.422). The CIE values agree with the reported values of Ca10Si6O21Cl2:Eu2+ (yellowish green, x=0.265, y=0.520) by Ding et al. [33]. This is consistent with the red shift of emission spectra and the emission intensity change of two emission bands of I EuI/I EuII. This phosphor has potential as a color-tunable material for lighting and displays.
Fig. 5
CIE chromaticity coordinates of Ca10Si6O21Cl2:xEu2+ (x=0.01–0.09)

Section2.Heading: Two luminescence centers and energy transfer
Section2.Para:
Figure 6 shows the excitation spectra by monitoring the emission bands at 430 nm, 540 nm, and 610 nm, which consist of broad absorption at 300–450 nm from the 4f–5d transition of Eu2+ ions. The excitation spectra of λ ex=540 nm and λ ex=610 nm have similar profiles, which are very different from that of λ ex=430 nm. The luminescence decay curves of 430 nm and 540 nm under the excitation of 355 nm in the sample Ca10Si6O21Cl2:0.07Eu2+ are shown in Fig. 7. They have different lifetimes 0.28 μs (430 nm EuI) and 0.65 μs (540 nm EuII).
Fig. 6
The excitation spectra of Ca10Si6O21Cl2:0.07Eu2+ by monitoring the emission bands at 430 nm, 540 nm, and 610 nm. λ em=430 nm is shifted upward to have a clear vision
Fig. 7
The luminescence decay curves of 430 nm and 540 nm under the excitation of 355 nm in sample Ca10Si6O21Cl2:0.07Eu2+

Moreover, the emission spectra have different shapes at the excitation of 300 nm and 425 nm, as shown in Fig. 8, which corresponds to the typical 4f65d1→4f7 transition of the Eu2+ ion. The different excitation spectra and the lifetimes for the two emission bands EuI and EuII confirm that there are two distinct Eu2+ centers in Ca10Si6O21Cl2 lattices.
Fig. 8
The normalized luminescence spectra of Ca10Si6O21Cl2:0.07Eu2+ under the excitation of 300 nm and 425 nm

As shown in Fig. 4, the emission intensity and spectrum shape of the two emission bands are affected by Eu2+-doping concentration. The positions of EuII were red shifted with increasing Eu2+ content. Usually, emission positions of Eu2+ ions in a host are influenced by the crystal field around the Eu2+ ions and the nephelauxetic effect (decrease of inter-electronic repulsion parameters of valence electrons due to covalency of bonds between the dopant and the ligands) [35].

However, the two aspects cannot explain the red shift of Eu2+ emission in Ca10Si6O21Cl2:xEu2+. As seen in Fig. 1b, upon increasing Eu2+ doping, the lattice has an expansion due to the smaller ionic radius of Ca2+ in comparison to Eu2+. This should cause a decrease in the splitting of the 5d energy levels due to the crystal-field effect that would consequently lead to a blue shift of the 5d–4f luminescence [36]. This can be reflected by relative intensity among two Eu2+ centers. The result indicates that the energy transfer can occur between EuI and EuII with increasing Eu2+ concentration. Hence, the red shift of the emission band could be explained by the energy transfer among Eu2+ ions. The distance between Eu2+ ions becomes shorter with increasing Eu2+ doping. This increases the probability of energy transfer of Eu2+ ions. The increase in the probability for non-radiative energy transfer in the 5d level causes a shift in the emission peak toward longer wavelengths with increasing Eu2+ doping [37].

The energy transfer can be confirmed by the doping concentration dependent luminescence lifetime of the Eu(I) site (430 nm) in Ca10Si6O21Cl2:xEu2+ (x=0.01–0.09). Figure 9 shows the luminescence decay curves of the Eu(I) site (430 nm) under the excitation of 355 nm. It is found that the curve of x=0.01 keeps nearly an exponential decay with a lifetime of 0.44 μs. With increasing doping level, the decay becomes non-exponential and the lifetime is shorter and shorter with increasing Eu concentration. This confirms that the energy transfer happens.
Fig. 9
The luminescence decay curves of Eu(I) site (430 nm) in Ca10Si6O21Cl2:xEu2+ (x=0.01–0.09) under the excitation of 355 nm

Very similar effects have been observed in silicate phosphors such as Sr2SiO4:Eu2+ [38] and BaMg2Al6Si9O30:Eu2+ [39] and nitrates such as a-SiAlON:Eu2+ [37], Ba2Si5N8:Eu2+ [40], and CaSi2O2N2:Eu2+ [41]: Eu2+ luminescence exhibits two distinct bands (denoted as a high-energy center EuI and a low-energy center EuII) due to 4f65d1→4f7; the energy transfer from EuI to EuII can be confirmed with increasing Eu2+ doping. The energy transfer probability among Eu2+ ions themselves increased due to the increase of Eu2+ concentration. So, it is reasonable that the energy transfer is possible from the high-energy level to the low-energy level, causing the red shift [38, 42].

Section2.Heading: The thermal property
Section2.Para:
The thermal properties of Eu2+-doped Ca10Si6O21Cl2 were investigated by the temperature-dependent emission spectra. Figure 10 presents the temperature-dependent luminescence intensity of Ca10Si6O21Cl2:0.07Eu2+. At 150 °C, the emission intensity decreases by about 12.5 % of the initial value at 20 °C, indicating a weak thermal quenching behavior. The activation energy (ΔE) for the thermal quenching of the Eu2+ emission was determined by a modified Arrhenius equation as follows [1]: 1
$$ I_{\mathrm{T}} = \frac{I_{0}}{1 + c\exp( - \frac{\Delta E}{kT})}, $$ where I 0 is the initial emission intensity, I T is the intensity at different temperatures, ΔE is the activation energy of thermal quenching, c is a constant for a certain host, and k is the Boltzmann constant (8.617×10−5 eV K−1). The inset in Fig. 10 plots ln((I 0/I T)–1) vs. 1000/T, which is linear with a slope of −4.05. According to Eq. (1), the activation energy ΔE was calculated to be 0.35 eV. The results show that Ca10Si6O21Cl2:Eu2+ has efficient luminescence and good thermal stability.
Fig. 10
The temperature-dependent luminescence intensity of Ca10Si6O21Cl2:0.07Eu2+. Inset is the calculation for the activation energies of the thermal quenching fitted in Eq. (1)

Ca10Si6O21Cl2:Eu2+ phosphors have no sensitivity to moisture in the open air. The photoluminescence quantum efficiency (QE) of Ca10Si6O21Cl2:0.07Eu2+ phosphor, i.e. internal QE, was measured to be 30 % at the excitation of 400 nm light at 300 K. It is possible to further develop this material to be a green-emitting phosphor.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: Green-emitting halosilicate Ca10Si6O21Cl2:Eu2+ was prepared by a solid state reaction method and displays characteristic two-peak emission spectra with a high energy emission band at about 430 nm (EuI) and another at 540 nm (EuII). The luminescence properties of the two emission bands show a dependence on the Eu2+ doping. With increasing Eu2+ concentration, EuI keeps nearly the same wavelength at 430 nm and decreases its intensity quickly; however, EuI shows a red shift and an increasing intensity. Consequently, the spectra are dominated by the Eu II emission band. This is ascribed to energy migration and energy transfer from EuI to EuII. It can be suggested that there are two cation sites, i.e. CaI and CaII, in the lattice for Eu2+ to occupy. The crystal fields surrounding EuII are stronger than that of EuI. The temperature-dependent luminescence shows that the phosphor has an excellent thermal stability on thermal quenching. The activation energy ΔE was calculated to be 0.35 eV. The luminescence color of Ca10Si6O21Cl2:xEu2+ can be tuned from bluish green (x=0.01) to green (x=0.03–0.05) and yellowish green (x=0.07–0.09) by adjusting the Eu2+ doping. The results indicate that the produced Eu2+-doped Ca10Si6O21Cl2 has a potential application as a color-tunable green-emitting material.
